text:
I listened to this song the night my girlfriend left me. It's ironic, I viewed it then as a period of my life ending. But little did I know it was really beginning...

This song is the perfect representation of such feelings. A journey ending so more can take their place.

text: I got stuck in this game back when I was first playing it around 1997, moved on to FFVII and kinda forgot about it.  Ten years later I decided to finally beat it.  The graphics, gameplay, and story all seemed fairly dated by then, but the music truly struck me as timeless, as I loved it equally when I was 11 and when I was 21.

author: legisu

text: I am inclined to disagree. It was the structure of the plots.Tthe language in the original, was far more charming then the remake. The flow was poetic.  Usually, philosophy and ideals were often woven in the old RPG game plots that was grander and oftetimes bordered the plot.. Then again this is from a writer's perspective. I was drawn in very heavily then -and it couldn't have been nostaligia because I had just played it.

author: Meishali

text: Very true, I enjoyed the Shadow Heart series, and the Tales of the Abyss had a really good plot and the gameplay was a lot of fun! They are there. But the original Wild Arms, had a kind of charm that the games of that generation had, that newer games lack. I can't quite put my finger on it, but -- it's there. But that's only my opinion too. =)

author: royi20s

text:
Just like Music in general, as time goes by, things change, and they never go back to what they were.
I love this game more than just about any, and I truly wish games these days could have the great story and amazing OSTs games back in the day have. 
All people care about these days is game play. But when you think about it, an RPG should be like a good book! Story and mood are everything.
Wild Arms is one of the games that knows where the efforts should be focused.

author: Darkmage1293

text:
Pff. Just no. I'd take any of the first three Wild Arms soundtracks over anything he's composed. Not that he's bad at all, but they just don't seem to have as much... personality. There's something to be said for someone who can make a track that sounds good about anywhere, of course, but Michiro Naruke is amazing at crafting a setting through the music she composed for this series.

Either way, this "series" gets massive kudos for a Wild Arms sendoff. A very appropriate track choice.
author: Lady Miaow

text: Uematsu is not god, pal. He has composed hundreds of songs and only about 2% is good. The only good things he's done are from Chrono Trigger (3 songs) and Final Fantasy III (almost the whole soundtrack). Final Fantasy III is his masterpiece, but he died there.
